problem_text:
a) By definition the commutator length of an element z of the derived subgroup of a group G is the least possible number of commutators from G whose product is equal to z. Does there exist a simple group on which the commutator length is not bounded?
b) Does there exist a finitely presented simple group on which the commutator length is not bounded?
V. G. Bardakov
answer:
a) Simple groups with this property were constructed in (J. Barge, ´E. Ghys, Math. Ann., 294 (1992), 235–265), and finitely generated simple ones in (A. Muranov, Int. J. Algebra Comput., 17 (2007), 607–659).
b) Yes, there does (P.-E. Caprace, K. Fujiwara, Geom. Funct. Anal., 19 (2010), 1296–1319).
